rules.text: Be professional. Maintain high standards of professional competence, conduct, and ethical practice when sharing and discussing work related to computing. Know and respect existing rules pertaining to professional work.

Be respectful.
Respect the work required to produce new ideas, inventions, creative works, and computing artifacts. Respect privacy. Honor confidentiality.

Be inclusive.
Diversity and inclusion are central to ACM's mission. We do not tolerate any kind of discrimination against anyone because of their age, gender, race, ethnicity, religion, disability, sexual orientation, or any other distinguishing characteristic or trait.

Be accessible.
We encourage you to adopt inclusive practices when posting your content. Best practices include providing alternative text for media, and more.

Be honest.
Computing professionals should be honest about their qualifications and forthright about any circumstances that may lead to either real or perceived conflicts of interest.

Be friendly.
Feel free to be conversational, personal, and fun! Fill up your profile page to tell us who you are, use computing-related hashtags to increase discoverability outside of this server. Engage with other users' content by meaningful re-tooting and commenting.

records.text: The solution is crude. Currently the "label" is just a string ("cuda", ignoring the gencodes for now) that goes into the `requiredSystemFeatures` attribute of the .drv; A host not configured to advertise support for the "feature" would refuse to start the build.If a host declares the "cuda" system feature, the expectation is that it's configured to relax the soundbox when a derivation asks for it (there's a nixos option to set up a hook to take care of this)

records.text: Nix relies on sandboxing to guarantee "completeness": since a derivation can't go browse the filesystem or the network without declaring what it needs upfront, one can't ship an incomplete derivation, i.e. one can't "forget" a dependency.Some dependencies are more complex than "store paths": that a derivation only builds on an aarch64 machine is a fact important to "completeness"; Nixpkgs simply express this as a special attribute in the derivation. CUDA is no different

records.text: Nix relies on sandboxing to guarantee "completeness": since a derivation can't go browse the filesystem or the network without declaring what it needs upfront, one can't ship an incomplete derivation, i.e. one can't "forget" a dependency.Some dependencies are more complex than "store paths": that a derivation only builds on an aarch64 machine is a fact important to "completeness"; Nixpkgs simply express this as a special attribute in the derivation. CUDA is no different

records.text: Nix relies on sandboxing to guarantee "completeness": since a derivation can't go browse the filesystem or the network without declaring what it needs upfront, one can't ship an incomplete derivation, i.e. one can't "forget" a dependency.Some dependencies are more complex than "store paths": that a derivation only builds on an aarch64 machine is a fact important to "completeness"; Nixpkgs simply express this as a special attribute in the derivation. CUDA is no different

Your response must be only the score number and anything else.

records.text: The power of laziness is great, but formal reasoning about its costs is notoriously elusive. In our ICFP 2024 paper "Story of Your Lazy Function's Life", we propose a solution based on a bidirectional demand semantics.  Find out more in our preprint: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2406.14787
